official-title.#text:
To adjust the boundary of the Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park to include the Wallis
			 House and Harriston Hill, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park Boundary Adjustment Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park Boundary Adjustment Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
on
			 June 26, 1935. Prior to 1935, parts of the park had been acquired and
			 protected by Civil War veterans and the War Department.

text.#text: Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park was authorized as a unit of the

Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park protects Kennesaw Mountain and Kolb’s Farm, which are
			 battle sites along the route of General Sherman’s 1864 campaign to take
			 Atlanta.

Most of the park protects Confederate positions and strategy. The Wallis House is one of the few
			 original structures remaining from the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain
			 associated with Union positions and strategy.
The Wallis House is strategically located next to a Union signal station at Harriston Hill.

quote.#tail: , and generally depicted on the map titled

quote.#text: Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park, Proposed Boundary Adjustment
